Quis autem vel eum iure reprehenderit qui in ea voluptate velit esse quam nihil molestiae consequatur, vel illum qui dolorem eum fugiat quo voluptas nulla pariaturClarify Business ObjectivesIn this challenge, you will choose a vision statement for an app dev project, create success indicators, and create a list of product features.It's important to get your Agile teamâs work off on the right footing. Weâll talk about the importance of a good problem statement, which helps you confirm that youâre focusing on the right set of issues. Equally important are the vision statement, success criteria, and scope, which together set the target that you and your team are aiming for as you build out your solution. Introductionhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=87FDctNdUOwBuilding a Problem StatementSed ut perspiciatis unde omnis iste natus error sit voluptatem accusantium doloremque laudantium, totam rem aperiam, eaque ipsa quae ab illo inventore veritatis et quasi architecto beatae vitae dicta sunt explicabo.

Neque porro quisquam est, qui dolorem ipsum quia dolor sit amet, consecteturDemonstration: Creating a Vision Statement<Introduction>In this video, your instructor will demonstrate how to write user stories. </Introduction><LaunchMovie>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PnbGirPTgF0</LaunchMovie></Movie></ParaBlock></Topic><Topic xy-guid="32eb5a27-015d-4722-95ed-45bfd8dfd315"><Title>What is a Feature?Adipisci velit, sed quia non numquam eius modi tempora incidunt ut labore et dolore magnam aliquam quaerat voluptatem. Ut enim ad minima veniam, quis nostrum exercitationem ullam corporis suscipit laboriosam, nisi ut aliquid ex ea commodi consequatur?

Quis autem vel eum iure reprehenderit qui in ea voluptate velit esse quam nihil molestiaePractice:Dolores Eos Match each term with it's definitionChallenge Introductionhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkDWslo13UMChallenge: Clarify Business ObjectivesRead the FoodOn Case Study.Select the best vision statement for the FoodOn app project.Create a list of success indicators.Create a list of features.Perform a Kano analysis for each feature. Establish and Manage a BacklogIn this challenge, you will write and prioritize user stories, and update a backlog in response to change.A backlog is an essential part of making sure your agile team is doing the right work at the right time. Think of it as a single source for what needs to be accomplished in order to satisfy the business. It contains all identified user stories and they are estimated, organized, and prioritized. If youâre an agile BA, youâll need to know what goes into creating a backlog and what you need to do to make sure that it is serving the team and your business well.Introductionhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YuCbQCnoIzIWhat is a User Story?User stories are short, simple descriptions of a feature told from the perspective of the person who desires the new capability, usually a user or customer of the system. They typically follow a simple template:
As a <type of user>, I want <some goal> so that <some reason>.

User stories are often written on index cards or sticky notes, stored in a shoe box, and arranged on walls or tables to facilitate planning and discussion. As such, they strongly shift the focus from writing about features to discussing them. In fact, these discussions are more important than whatever text is written.</RichText></ParaBlock></Topic><Topic xy-guid="59aa1269-7a76-442b-a88e-a445a6ea876a"><Title>Demonstration: Writing User Stories</Title><ParaBlock xy-guid="d6e20add-d7e2-4f74-aebb-40a9963faefb"><Movie ShowControls="true" StartOnLoad="false" height-pixel="" width-pixel="" wrap="" xy-guid="2063f340-aea9-4c65-af35-6d538bd006aa"><Title>Writing User Stories</Title><Introduction>In this video, your instructor will demonstrate how to write user stories. </Introduction><LaunchMovie>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yux26dR2s_c</LaunchMovie></Movie></ParaBlock></Topic><Topic xy-guid="b3da2263-1cef-420f-a1d3-153728fc12af"><Title>What is a Backlog?</Title><ParaBlock xy-guid="d960fbb1-a452-4a13-b80b-f4934031906e"><RichText>A backlog is a list of features or technical tasks which the team maintains and which, at a given moment, are known to be necessary and sufficient to complete a project or a release:
if an item on the backlog does not contribute to the project's goal, it should be removed;
on the other hand, if at any time a task or feature becomes known that is considered necessary to the project, it should be added to the backlog.

These "necessary and sufficient" properties are assessed relative to the team's state of knowledge at a particular moment; the backlog is expected to change throughout the project's duration as the team gains knowledge.

The backlog is the primary point of entry for knowledge about requirements, and the single authoritative source defining the work to be done.</RichText></ParaBlock></Topic><Topic xy-guid="e7217bed-d7d5-40f4-8a93-cb426ceb2871"><Title>Practice: User Story Terminology</Title><QuestionBlock xy-guid="fa6c8e1c-9492-4ea4-8c6e-867b24be6d17"><MatchingActivity PresoType="DragArrow" Weight="1.0" xy-guid="3fc72dfa-2a34-48e6-8c52-6829a1f283b6"><QuestionStem><RichText>Match each term with it's definition</RichText></QuestionStem><Option><Distractor><RichText>User story</RichText></Distractor><Match><RichText>A concise statement of functionality</RichText></Match></Option><Option><Distractor><RichText>Epic</RichText></Distractor><Match><RichText>A statement of functionality that would take significant effort to implement</RichText></Match></Option><Option><Distractor><RichText>Theme</RichText></Distractor><Match><RichText>A group of statements of functionality that share a common attribute</RichText></Match></Option></MatchingActivity></QuestionBlock></Topic></ContentGroup><ContentGroup name="Challenge" xy-guid="d525de15-4436-4aa0-a7a0-855ce8cc463c"><Topic xy-guid="8b26cece-8456-4a89-a04b-3a121ee03725"><Title>Challenge Introduction</Title><ParaBlock xy-guid="4cef0fcd-249b-4957-aacf-5f2542e227b4"><Movie ShowControls="true" StartOnLoad="false" height-pixel="" width-pixel="" wrap="" xy-guid="6ad9e02c-4d2d-48e0-a55f-208cf00eb5b5"><LaunchMovie>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pkDWslo13UM</LaunchMovie></Movie></ParaBlock><Topic xy-guid="7614cc19-cbd2-4285-95c5-2d4bdb64c9f7"><Title>Challenge: Establish and Manage a Backlog</Title><ParaBlock xy-guid="bda04ccd-1178-4240-95b4-6f839c82fa59"><RichText>Based on the case study and the observation notes from the restaurant, write a set of 6 user stories representing the needs of at least 3 different actors...

</RichText><List ListMarker="Bullet" xy:guid="d4e98d3d-8710-418f-a899-418aa7589f37"><ItemBlock><Item><ItemPara>Read the observation notes from the T. Road restaurant and review previous case study materials related to FoodOn.</ItemPara></Item><Item><ItemPara>Based on the material at hand, write a set of five user stories that describe useful features. Use at least two different actors across your stories. </ItemPara></Item><Item><ItemPara>Prioritize the user stories based on the available information.</ItemPara></Item><Item><ItemPara>Review the change scenario in which the product owner introduces new user stories. If any of the stories are epics, split them into smaller stories.</ItemPara></Item><Item><ItemPara>Reprioritize your existing user stories and the new stories introduced by the product owner.</ItemPara></Item></ItemBlock></List></ParaBlock></Topic></Topic></ContentGroup></Lesson></Lessons></IA>
